comments.commentBody:
"The construction industry is still a disaster ..."

You can say that again, but not in the sense meant here: a huge percentage of the popcorn houses built in the last decade or two are architecturally the equivalent of junk-food. They were designed, built and sold to maximize profit and minimize investment and they are built of garbage, 2x4s, chipboard, construction beams made of wood chips glued together by gunk, all usually covered with a fake veneer of "class" with columned porticos or "designer" motifs of some other time tacked onto them to justify the million bucks and up costs to the naive and foolish buyers. These "buildings" won't last 20 years, nor were they intended to. They were intended to make a big profit and nothing else. They are a typical example of American capitalism in its worst phase, and as could have been predicted, it does indeed produce a disaster.

Of course McMansions are not going away.  All one needs to do is look at the resurgence of giant unneeded truck and SUVs now that gasoline is cheap again.  It is sad, but Americans want big big big.  The Democrats have done nothing to make gasoline more expensive, and continues to back mortgages for the overhoused.

If anyone is interested, the majority of the footage in the Arcade Fire video is from a 1957 Redbook flim called..."In the Suburbs".

I think it can be found on YouTube, but here's another link: http://www.archive.org...

Both our Military and the German Military have forecast peak oil scenarios within the next 5 years. Urban housing and farming (vacant lots are about 20% for the average city of > 1,000,000 + pop.) seem the likeliest trend for the transition period ahead.

http://www.zerohedge.com...

The U.S. Department of Energy commissioned a report by Robert Hirsch to examine peak oil and its potential consequences to the US in 2005 . The introduction stated:

“The peaking of world oil production presents the U.S. and the world with an unprecedented risk management problem. As peaking is approached, liquid fuel prices and price volatility will increase dramatically, and, without timely mitigation, the economic, social, and political costs will be unprecedented. Viable mitigation options exist on both the supply and demand sides, but to have substantial impact, they must be initiated more than a decade in advance of peaking.”

The most recent Gallup poll asking for the most important problem facing the US today had no responses concerning energy limitation which seems to be entirely off the public's radar screen.

What has been lost over time is where solidity is built into a home, such as hand-plastered walls, wood windows, oak floors (veneer floors do not count), and other details.  Toll-type houses are heavy on brass accents, marble floor and the ubiquitous granite countertop, but hidden from view are plastic pipes, thin wallboard glued onto undersize wood beams, and "engineered" materials, which means anything made as cheap as possible.  A house from the forties holds up better than a McMansion over a span of a decade.

The stately homes of earlier time periods that were in the cities were changed into apartments, offices, and other uses.   These older homes tended to be architecturally more beautiful and better built and the easier zoning of the time allowed for the transition of uses.  One wonders if this is possible today.

Reform is something not compatible with the realities in the political system we have.

I will make a "wild guess" in that the political elite will continue to prop up housing values through various gimmicks and tactics instead of addressing the root of the housing bubble which are inflated prices. The mortgage interest deduction is such a gimmick.

The GSEs essentially have a monopoly on mortgages at this point and refuse to let the market find its real bottom by delaying foreclosures and withholding properties from the market. Housing prices have to go down by a least another 50%. That is especially the case in the major coastal cities.

Unless it is much cheaper to buy than to rent the younger generations have little incentive to buy. The loss in mobility along with the sky high costs of maintenance and other responsibilities simply do not make sense. HOAs in the range of $300-$1000 are very common these days. This is complete insanity.

Personally I sit on a large amount of cash. Doing the numbers I have a better return by letting it sit in a one percent savings account and "throwing away" money renting compared to dumping it into property. I can wait for the real crash. For as many years as I have to.

Expanding into ever larger households has become the norm of American society. Pre 50's era household averaged about 1000 square feet compared to today's 2200 square foot home. A large home is not necessary to live a fulfilling life but rather obstructs from what is important. Freeing yourself from unnecessary material will result in a more simple life allowing focus on family, relationships and living in the moment. Live more with less.

What's more impressive a multi-millionaire living in a modest 1500 square foot home or living in a 5000 square foot home?

Well if I take a "the sky isn't falling" perspective on the American economy, I would say this article is probably correct. Just as the old Victorians got split up into multi-unit dwellings (whether condos or rentals), so too will many of the McMansions. New building is still going to mostly be among people with lots of money, and they will still build houses larger than they really need, but you won't see a lot of "pretend rich" people working $20/hr jobs and trying to live like they earn that much per minute. They buy previously occupied homes, and right now in my area the real competition is around homes hovering around 1000 sq. ft. These are getting snapped up within days of going on the market, and the appraiser says that trend is accelerating.

The size and cost of housing has always reflected what buyers have been able to afford. That was true for the first wave of mega-mansions built by the "robber-barons" of the 1800's, the next wave of Wall Street millionaires of the 1920's, and the "dot-com" billionaires of recent times. The bubble that just burst was based on what people could afford - or, more accurately, what they thought they could afford. McMansions are not dead; there will just be a lot fewer built. As the economy regains health and strength, these hard times will fade from memory and those who can, will once again show their economic/financial prowess through conspicuous consumption in all things. Just reread Thorstein Veblen's "The Theory Of The Leisure Class" to see there is nothing new under the sun, as far as showing off one's wealth.

Actually it is going to be interesting this next decade.  The 2000-2002 stock market bubble redistributed wealth from the lower to the higher.  The last decade has done more of it - the question for real estate is where are the mature adults who no longer  fit into a 20 or 30 something house and who did not manage to buy a home during their 60 years or so, are going to retire -  and how on social security purely - and those who were not in the middle class for most of their years?  Where do those who retire on 10,000 or 15,000 from social security with no other assets or income go to live when they cannot drive for the most part and cannot pay the rents in the more urban areas?  At 75 youcannot  just "find another part time job"  etc in this market or the next?  what are the seniors who are retiring on rather subsistence level going to live?  This was pointed out as early as 1984 when seniors were outliving their means and affordable housing was being built..I am not there myself but know people who are.  Where are all these people going to live for another decade?  Just wondering

For service oriented businesses, we're blessed with great technology so no need to pay high rents except for client meetings as she said and often then you can meet clients in their conference rooms.

For morale, Brooks, you might want to help employees with career development and motivational training. That's been a proven morale booster when money is tight...or even when it's not.

Until the measure of a person's "success" isn't measured by how much of a home but the quality of their home people will strive to achieve the maximum amount of home that they can afford (or perhaps cannot afford).

Like most things size really doesn't matter but unfortunately will allows be the metric for how something's worth is judged. It is a shame that there never was a quality over quantity paradigm shift in homes. Probably would have made the housing bubble and collapse a much less dire and damaging event.

Is vanity dead?  No way.  The housing trends will go the way of society, Rich,Poor, shrinking middle class.  Larger houses are a burden, but mass-produced square-footage train wrecks are the albatross-really expensive to maintain, and horrible build-quality.  Why would the junk they built the last 10 years, hold value? Real Mansions will get Greater, poor people will get nicer digs (they have to live close to the mansion to service it), and the McMansion, a building invented to capitalize on the false equity of Baby Boomers, will quietly survive along with its inhabitants-who got away with the ruse.

Affordable apartments are urgently needed in the major metropolitan areas of this country, but only million-dollar pieds-a-terre are being built. Office workers, teachers, cops, and others who work in cities need to live in cities and commute to their jobs by foot or efficient public transportation, but the cities as well as the hinterlands of the U.S.A. are owned and operated for the benefit of the rich, the middle class be damned.

I agree with your thesis that the tax deduction is regressive, and with your assertion that the upper limit is probably too high, but I don't agree with your argument that home ownership should not be encouraged. If our government is going to use tax policy to encourage anything, I would vote for that to include home ownership. As a liberal it pains me to say this, but when you look at the crime maps for city after city, what you see is that the crime follows the rentals. The higher the percentage of owner occupied dwellings in any neighborhood, the lower the crime rate. Check it out for yourself if you don't believe me. I know because I researched neighborhoods extensively in a recent home search, and crime maps were my first test before deciding to even bother looking at the photos of the interior of the home.

I want to make it easier for working class people to afford to live in fully owner-occupied neighborhoods. I don't accept that the price of being working class has to be that you have bullets flying past your windows. The mortgage interest tax deduction makes homes more affordable for these families, and for people like myself, who simply want to live in a place where I'll have the same neighbors for many years and they will all be taking care of the home they live in and forming bonds with the people around them. Home ownership fosters commitment to community and reduction in crime. It is in the vital interests of this nation that it be supported.

However, again, it is true that at the upper income limits it needs no support. Those people can and will buy homes with or without the interest deductions. So that's just good money out the window.
Forgot history? So, repeat it. Is this a reprint from 1993?... or possibly 1981? Nothing has cahaged. The bad is almost over. Sorry, no news there! Time to buy.

What I hope to see in housing is beginning to appear accross the board, from a consumer consumption viewpoint.  Many people are asking: "Do I really NEED all of this____?"  You fill in the blank.  The "Not so small house" ought to grow in popularity as more and more see 30 foot foyers and drive in Bathrooms as a waste of space and heating/cooling expenses.  We may well still require 3 car garages, but the bays will likely house highly fuel efficient autos and perhaps somthing utilitarian that does not guzzle gas.  People do not need all the space we Americans have been conditioned to expect.  If we collectively awaken we will clearly see the devastating impact the excesses from the 80 until recently have had not only on our soil but also abroad.  Less really is more if it is done well.  Let us all embrace efficiency and adorn it with a sense of modern style.  We can still live well without killing trees and wasting megawatts in biblical amounts.  Here's to the hope we not only have what we want, but also that we want and enjoy all that we have.  Even if it is less than supersize.

While the McMansions of the past housing boom have and will continue to be out of reach for more Americans, they will continue to appeal to the growing wealthy class who will continue to buy them just because they can. While the sense of pride of home ownership and the guardedly secure feeling of owning a home are priceless, the actual financial benefits of home ownership are suspect when one calculates all of the costs associated with buying, selling and all cost incurred while living in a house (including maintenance costs, improvement costs and miscellaneous fees, not to mention mortgage interest and property tax payments), even while factoring in moderate appreciation and the tax deductions associated with mortgage interest and property taxes. I believe most homeowners actually lose money over the life of owning a home. Furthermore, I believe the losses are generally greater the larger the house. The cost of energy to run a home is directly proportionate to the size of the home, too. That being said, I still don't think the recent housing crisis and recession will ultimately turn recent home owners into renters in a big way. Owning a home will always be very desirable.

I am certain architects are capable of designing smaller 1500 to 1800 square foot homes that are highly functional, practical and feel much larger. All levels of governments should be creating incentives for builders to build these smaller, efficient homes and buyers to purchase them.

No, the McMansions are not going away. This country has a long history of wretched excess. The average American has the appetites, maturity, and attention span of a teenager. Note that they have already decided to dump Obama because he has not fixed the financial catastrophe in his 18 months in office - and they are ready to vote back the Republicans whose policies are largely responsible for the current mess. McMansions are the least of our problems. They are merely the most visible symptom.

As John Williams of shadowstats.com reports, real unemployment is at 22%. One out of every eight Americans is on food stamps. Our manufacturing base has been shipped off to slave wage countries, and the housing Ponzi scheme is bust. There's a 12-month backlog of unsold homes; probably twice that many when you consider the ones being held off the market by banks and by homeowners who just plain can't sell as they watch their home drop in value. So, no, there will not be some magical rebound in housing or a resurgence of McMansions. The easy credit and criminal mortgage schemes that inflated the bubble are gone for good. My guess is that the millions of empty homes across this country are going to wind up with squatters in them as we sink further into The Great Depression II. It hasn't even gotten ugly yet.
If I had the energy and know-how, I would embark on a co-housing project. Lots of greenspace, communal kitchen (and private of course), along with a village-like atmosphere, and a community garden.

I believe one change we will see in the not-to-distant future involves driving.  Most of our communities today are built around the idea that the automobile is a readily available tool for everyone except children.  What happens when the boomers start reaching an age that they can no longer operate a vehicle safely?  Many of the retirement communities that exist today do not have public transportation, and families do not necessarily live close enough for children to fill in that gap.  I believe our community planners will be forced to deal with this problem either through long range planning (hopefully), or crisis management.

Well, I don't know about the divorce aspect, but girls most certainly do need as many involved parents as they can find. Among friends and acquaintances of my generation (middle Baby Boomer), I have noticed (anecdotally, of course) that every woman who is a successful professional had a very involved father. The kind of dad who knew their friends' names; drove them to practices, rehearsals, and games; read to them; played board games with them; and willingly spent scarce leisure time with them. A child-centric dad, in other words.

I didn't have that kind of father. When I was a young woman listening to another young woman talking about how her dad loved to take them to the movies or canoeing or to track meets, I would be amazed. My father never made time just for us; if we wanted to hang out with him we did what he wanted to do. I spent a lot of time at the golf driving range and waiting in the car while he went into "the factory" on a Saturday to check how the weekend shift was going.

I didn't mind any of that, but neither did I have any expectations that he would make any effort to meet me halfway in my world.

So I'm really pretty sure that most women do not make the calculation that their daughter doesn't need a father. The calculatiion they might be making, however, is that their daughter doesn't need THIS particular father.

McMansions just have bigger "made in China" furniture ... and a really big clock (currently on sale for $39.99 at Bed, Bath and Beyond).

The ceilings are higher, the rooms are connected, and there's lots of rooflines to add expense.

Granite counters? Radon.
Style? All the same. Dark brown Costco furniture.

I'm so glad we've stayed in our normal home. It's paid for, we have plenty of extra money, we have no debt whatsoever, and we laugh at the sheets in the windows of the McMansions a half-mile away.
